results.title: China Sentences Canadian Businessman to 11 Years in Prison
results.abstract: The prosecution of Michael Spavor has been widely seen as political retaliation by China against Canada for the detention of a Chinese technology executive.

results.title: A Yearlong Cry for Help, Then Death After an Assault
results.abstract: Daniela Espirito Santo died after an assault by her boyfriend, who had been arrested, then released, by police. Her case is emblematic of Britain’s failure to protect victims of domestic abuse.

results.title: As U.S. Leaves Afghanistan, History Suggests It May Struggle to Stay Out
results.abstract: A decade ago, a U.S. withdrawal from Iraq opened the door for the Islamic State. Will the withdrawal from Afghanistan do the same for the Taliban?

results.title: Her Death Shook Japan. It May Not Shift Refugee Rules.
results.abstract: Wishma Rathnayake wasted away in a migrant detention center. An official report on her case placed little blame and offered only limited recommendations.

results.title: Europe Reopened to Americans. Why, It Asks, Hasn’t the U.S. Reciprocated?
results.abstract: America’s borders remain closed to most European travelers during the pandemic, even those fully vaccinated. With fears of the Delta variant raging, there appears to be no end in sight.

multimedia.caption: Peter Fuchs, 87, at his home in Hanover, Germany. On his way to the United States in May, he was told mid-journey that he could not board his flight to New York. The experience made him feel “helpless and broken down.”
multimedia.copyright: Gordon Welters for The New York Times

results.title: Algerian Soldiers Die Fighting Wildfires, President Says
results.abstract: At least 25 soldiers were killed saving residents from wildfires ravaging mountain forests and villages east of the capital, he said. The civilian death toll from the blazes rose to at least 17.

results.title: Ying-shih Yu, Renowned Scholar of Chinese Thought, Dies at 91
results.abstract: He believed that Chinese tradition was more varied and tolerant than critics thought it to be, and that it could be a vessel for enlightened values and democratic progress.
